Injunction.definition: an equitable remedy in the form of a court order compelling a party to do or refrain from doing a specified act compare cease-and-desist order at order
Injunction.origin: [Middle French injonction , from Late Latin injunction- injunctio , from Latin injungere to enjoin, from in- in + jungere to join]

affirmative injunction.definition: an injunction requiring a positive act on the part of the defendantin this entry

interlocutory injunction.definition: an injunction that orders the maintenance of the status quo between the parties prior to a final determination of the matterin this entry

mandatory injunction.definition: an injunction that compels the defendant to do some positive act rather than simply to maintain the situation as it was when the action was brought comparein this entry

per路ma路nent injunction.definition: an injunction imposed after a hearing and remaining in force at least until the defendant has complied with its provisions called also

preliminary injunction.definition: an interlocutory injunction issued before a trial for purposes of preventing the defendant from acting in a way that will irreparably harm the plaintiff's ability to enforce his or her rights at the trial called alsocompareat
preliminary injunction.note: Before a preliminary injunction can be issued, there must be a hearing with prior notice to the defendant. Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 65, the hearing and the trial may be consolidated.

prohibitory injunction.definition: an injunction that prohibits the defendant from taking a particular action and maintains the positions of the parties until there is a hearing to determine the matter in dispute
